content.webTitle: Sumner Redstone's salary cut as suit calls him incapable of running Viacom

fields.headline: Sumner Redstone's salary cut as suit calls him incapable of running Viacom
fields.bodyText: Sumner Redstone, the 92-year-old executive chairman of Viacom, received a reduction in salary in 2015 to a scant $2m as a shareholder lawsuit alleged that he was incapable of continuing to run the company. Redstone, by some accounts in very poor health, is said by his former caretaker, Manuela Herzer, to be suffering from much more serious declines in his abilities than the company has indicated. Previously a reliable presence on the company’s earnings calls, he has not spoken to investors on one since November 2014. Activist investor SpringOwl Asset Management is campaigning publicly against Dauman, Redstone, and Viacom’s “overpaid and lackey board”, according to a presentation to investors. Philippe Dauman, chief executive officer of Viacom, also saw a reduction in pay: his bonus was cut from $18.9m to $14m. Dauman’s salary was cut by 85%, according to Broadcasting & Cable, which said the company offered the salary information in response to the suit questioning Redstone’s competence. “Viacom has the oldest directors on average compared to any of their media peers at 66 (except for CBS),” the presentation said, noting that median pay for outside directors at the company was $314,000 – higher than at Disney, Time Warner, Fox, Scripps and AMC. “Did MTV get the idea for Cribs from the habits of Viacom directors?” “We believe almost 75% of the VIAB [Viacom’s ticker symbol] board are not independent by a reasonable definition,” the investor presentation concluded after offering a long list of directors it said were not independent. The investors went on to scold the company for overpaying Dauman and Tom Dooley, chief operating officer. “Is Dauman really worth 30% more than Disney’s Bob Iger?” they asked in the presentation, noting that more than half of Dauman’s compensation – a contractual $40m a year through 2018 – is in cash, not shares of the company. The charges against Dauman and the rest of Viacom’s leadership go well beyond simply lining their own pockets: SpringOwl said Viacom management had sold its hit cartoon SpongeBob Squarepants to Netflix for too little, too early, taking children away from all-important revenue-generating advertisements. The investors also allege that Viacom mishandled its stake in new-media company Vice, organized by former CEO Tom Freston (and subsequently bought out by Freston after Redstone fired him). More seriously, the shareholders pointed out that Viacom has been dropped by 60 separate rural cable operators, cutting into its passive income from cable subscriptions that simply don’t include Nickelodeon, MTV or Comedy Central anymore. And again, SpringOwl insinuated – as did Herzer in her suit – that Redstone is not responsible for his decisions at all. The group included as evidence a picture of a document ostensibly signed by Redstone in which his signature is a single wavy line that runs off the page. Through his company National Amusements, Redstone has been a major force in the American entertainment industry for 40 years, controlling not just Viacom, owner of Paramount Pictures and Comedy Central, among other assets, but broadcast network CBS and its assets, as well. Redstone conducted a successful hostile takeover bid in 1987, when he beat out a management-led investor group with a $3.4bn offer for the company in what an analyst characterized at the time as “a war of attrition”.
